Anthony \"Swoff\" Swofford.Action: Reflects on the harsh desert environment with a sense of acceptance and honesty.
Shows slight panic and vulnerability during physical training despite physical strength.
Physically strong during boot camp but shows slight panic and struggle performing squat thrusts, indicating initial difficulty despite effort.
Admits on behalf of another recruit to occasional drug use to relieve their burden during a harsh drill instructor interrogation, allowing the recruit to rest
Admits to having tried drugs (cocaine, marijuana, LSD) openly to DI Burke.
Accepts harsh treatment and verbal abuse from DI Burke without retaliation; stands with outcast recruits.
Displays sincere effort and nervousness trying to draw the footlocker on the blackboard despite pressure.
Internal monologue expressing complex emotions including desire to be loved and understood.
Successfully selected by DI Burke to be his 'scribe' based on perceived intelligence.
Struggles and is desperate while trying to draw the footlocker diagram as instructed.
Tries to explain the recruit's poor drawing despite harsh criticism; remains respectful and submissive under DI Burke's abuse.
Endures physical punishment without retaliation or complaint, showing tolerance and patience.
Appears defeated and unable to assert himself or correct misconceptions about his role, indicating insecurity and passivity.
No indication of warmth via friendliness or sincere connection; primarily reacts to abuse.
Fails to create an intelligible drawing as the recruit's scribe, appears confused and unable to respond competently under DI Burke's pressure
Maintains composure under physical and verbal abuse without outright breaking down or arguing back
Boy Swoff stands up full of emotion and begins to sing the Marine Corps hymn with his family present.
Loves his girlfriend Kristina and reciprocates her affection sincerely.
Mom shows motherly concern while preparing a USMC emblem T-shirt for Boy Swoff, indicating a close family relationship.
Internal voice acknowledges he was 'made in a war' and cannot watch a couple making love, indicating emotional detachment or discomfort with intimacy.
Reflects on being 'made in a war' and internalizes military identity from a young age.
Expresses emotion and patriotism by passionately singing 'From the halls of Montezuma' as a boy upon seeing news of military casualties.
Is physically hit and loses composure (face slammed into blackboard) during conflict.
Passively accepts parental influence over his future (mother ironing USMC emblem on shirt) and internalizes expectations.

Accepts the harsh reality and orders without argument after initial surprise, showing ability to adapt.
Mentions his desire to fail and get out, reflecting internal conflict and self-doubt.

Corrects Captain Curtis about the private’s drug use with calm, factual clarity.

Stands at attention in full uniform immediately after his outburst, then respectfully says 'Thank you sir.'
Reflects thoughtfully on Marine terminology and the coming changes to his life on the bus.
Reads The Myth of Sisyphus on the john, appears introspective and thoughtful.
Uses Ex-Lax gum excessively in an attempt to deal with constipation, leading to hospitalization.
